<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_linux_irq_notify:
```c
static int metal_linux_irq_notify(void)
{
	uint64_t val = 1;
	int ret;

	ret = write(irq_notify_fd, &val, sizeof(val));
	if (ret < 0) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR, "%s failed\n", __func__);
	}
	return ret;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function metal_linux_irq_notify:
static void metal_linux_irq_set_enable(struct metal_irq_controller *irq_cntr,
				       int irq, unsigned int state)
{
	int offset, ret;

	if (irq < irq_cntr->irq_base ||
	    irq >= irq_cntr->irq_base + irq_cntr->irq_num) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR, "%s: invalid irq %d\n",
			  __func__, irq);
		return;
	}
	offset = irq - linux_irq_cntr.irq_base;
	metal_mutex_acquire(&irq_lock);
	if (state == METAL_IRQ_ENABLE)
		metal_bitmap_set_bit(irqs_enabled, offset);
	else
		metal_bitmap_clear_bit(irqs_enabled, offset);
	metal_mutex_release(&irq_lock);
	/* Notify IRQ thread that IRQ state has changed */
	ret = metal_linux_irq_notify();
	if (ret < 0) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR,
			  "%s: failed to notify set %d enable\n",
			  __func__, irq);
	}
}
...
void metal_linux_irq_shutdown(void)
{
	int ret;

	metal_log(METAL_LOG_DEBUG, "%s\n", __func__);
	irq_handling_stop = true;
	metal_linux_irq_notify();
	ret = pthread_join(irq_pthread, NULL);
	if (ret) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR, "Failed to join IRQ thread: %d.\n",
			  ret);
	}
	close(irq_notify_fd);
	metal_mutex_deinit(&irq_lock);
}
...
void metal_sys_finish(void)
{

	/* Shutdown IRQ handling */
	metal_linux_irq_shutdown();
	metal_linux_bus_finish();
	close(_metal.pagemap_fd);

}
...
#define metal_log(level, fmt, __VA_ARGS__) ({if(_metal.common.log_handler&&level<=_metal.common.log_level)_metal.common.log_handler(level,metal_fmt(fmt),##__VA_ARGS__);\
})

Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
I selected all locations that either define metal_linux_irq_notify or call it directly, plus the metal_log macro (and its invocation) because metal_linux_irq_notify calls metal_log; the macro invokes _metal.common.log_handler and metal_fmt, which could be user-provided and thus is a potential indirect path back into library code. These fragments therefore need investigation for possible direct or indirect recursion.

Other code fragments were not included because they do not form call paths back to metal_linux_irq_notify: system calls and library calls such as write(), close(), pthread_join(), the bitmap and mutex helper calls (metal_mutex_acquire/release, metal_bitmap_set_bit/clear_bit), and simple assignments/condition checks cannot by themselves call back into metal_linux_irq_notify and so cannot create direct or indirect self-calls. Likewise, calls to metal_linux_bus_finish() and close(_metal.pagemap_fd) in metal_sys_finish do not reference metal_linux_irq_notify and are not part of a caller chain leading back to it. Therefore they do not need investigation for Rule 17.2 in this context.
